reviewText:
Better freeze your wallet before you throw everything into this money grave"
Frozen is a Disney franchise which has been used by Supervillian Studios to produce this Bejeweled clone F2P game. Frozen FF:SBF is clearly a game supposed to play on Pads/Tablet PCs. But who ever had the idea to bring it to Steam FORGOT TO INTEGRATE MOUSE CONTROLS.
That can be gamebreaking. For example when in higher levels there is a timelimit and you cannot reach a powerup in time because of the WASD & Spacebar controls. Apropos powerups: You see many at the beginning which are just for the tuorial levels. You will loose them after and get 1 powerup per each earned 75 stars. That's just ridiculous.

If you fail a level you also loose a life symbolized as a red heart. You start with 15 lives. But if they run out quickly you have to wait for your daily award and be lucky or BUY them in the store. This store is marvelous well integrated into Steam. 70 Hearts = 8.90 EUR
date:
Powerups 1 EUR each. After click you land directly from this awful graphics in the last checkout screen of Steam. Don't click there wrong! No sane man would buy this crap even accidently. Btw who is the target group for this game I wonder. Little kids? With this incorporated perfideous microtransactions system certainly not. Grownups maybe. But only if you have enough time and nerves.

The game itself is divided into two parts: Firstly the Free Fall (FF) is the SP and used to unlock stars and characters. Something tells me that you are barely able to unlock all characters for free. It gets  harder fastly because at lvl15 there are time limits introduced like 60 secs to reach 40k points. Your lives go away like cat lives. And the three star goal is even higher.

Interesting find: The game gives you the illusion everything is random. But I figured out the starting position in each level is always the same. So it's more like a puzzle which you have to solve quickly in time. That can be useful but also shows the bad quality of surprise. The game just knows if you are unable to make any further move and then randomizes slowly the map new.

The second mode is the Snowball Fight (SBF) which is MP (haha it's just local MP. You would not have expected here any ingenius netcode). You should have unlocked all characters in SP and already know how to play this game basically. Then you are able to puzzle again and do 50 snowball fights against yourself.

So if you are still interested to checkout this partly unfair & unbalanced
hoursPlayed: awful graphics & storyless masterpiece of negativity then go on."

After completing all levels in the game. I can finally write a review.

Frozen Free Fall is a matching game at its core and can be compared to games like: Candy Crush, Soda Saga, and Bejeweled. The only main difference is that it's based on the world of Frozen.

First things first, if you don't like Frozen, you will NOT enjoy this game.

A few quick things before I list the Pros and cons:

1) You don't have to pay anything to complete all levels, I didn't so you shouldn't have to either.
2) This game will make you want to buy stuff, trust me.
3) All characters can be unlocked for free.
4) There is now partial mouse support.

Pros:
+Lots of Levels
+Based in the world of Frozen
+Free to play
+Beautiful Unity based game (I was actually suprised at the character design looking so good)
+More content in the future (Hopefully Free)
+A well made port from the web based version
+Devs listen to the community for the most part
+Lots of variety in the levels

Cons:
-3 songs in the game. 1 song you hear so much that you will want to rip your hair out.
-An Obvious cash grab. I don't blame the devs for this though. Blame Disney.
-Some levels are so stupid hard that you are ALMOST forced to buy items without playing the levels over and over.
-Sound glitches when getting too big of a combo, its actually very funny XD
-No actual Songs, or voices from the movie.
-Only partial mouse support. I ended up not using the mouse anyway.

In conclusion, the game itself isnt all that bad. Yes it is a cash Grab for people that don't want to try hard. I give props the the Developers for making the game look so good on the unity engine! There are definitly better matching games out there though and I recommend you play them. Unless you really like Frozen. I will Recommend this game solely on the fact that its free and you dont have to pay anything other then your time.

reviewText:
Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight, a game based on the 2013 American 3D computer-animated musical fantasy comedy film produced by Walt Disney Animation Studios, Frozen, is a deep game that has to do with the life of Elsa and Anna. They go on throughout the game, as the title suggests, snowball fighting.
Frozen Free Fall is on many consoles and devices including PC, Playstation 4, and mobile devices.

Story- Many fans believe that Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight has to be exact with the movie rendition, yet it is so much better without connecting the movie with itself. The deep backstory for why Olaf and Anna must fight with snowballs makes the player ponder at life. This storyline is one of the most in depth stories I have ever seen in a video game, very near that of Mario Kart Wii.

Characters- A wide variety of your favorite Frozen characters are available for you to use and unlock. Although some are for real life currency, I guarantee that it will be worth the spare change.

Gameplay- A crazy puzzle to get through level to level, main menu to the actual game, Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight challenges the player to think creatively and act thoughtfully. The act of misclicking could end a game quick, whether it be the x-button to close the game or the jewel that could do absolutely nothing. Multiplayer is also an option if you want to play the game competitively. There may be a few balancing patches, for a skilled Olaf may beat any Elsa. Elsa may be the strongest character in this game, if not fiction as a whole.

Overall rating- 10/10
The game is an amazing example of how a game should be made for a movie. A game free of bugs, Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight allows a joyful time for everyone, besides the friend who is getting whooped in multiplayer. Items are given to the player to enhance their gameplay and give the game a more competitive nature. This game is honestly high in the rankings with Super Smash Bros. Melee for the Nintendo Gamecube, League of Legends, and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. I highly suggest that you get this game immediately even if you are not a fan of the movie Frozen.

reviewText:
You and I both visited this page for one or maybe even two of the same reasons:
* you enjoyed playing Candy Crush, and you were looking for a similar Steam game
* you loved the movie Frozen ,so you figured you would give this game a go

Before you install this game, I suggest you read a few of the reviews that actually give you some of the pros and cons of the gameplay of Frozen Freefall. I probably started off like you, reading some of the 5 to 6 word reviews and thought to myself, ehh I will just give it a try and see for myself. Here are my thoughts on this game.

When you start up the game, you will quickly realize that you do not have mouse support while using this game. You are to solely rely on the keyboard to navigate throughout the game. For me, this was already an annoyance, but I still wanted to give the game a fair shot. Once you continue through the story portion, you can then begin the actual game play. Like you can gather by screenshots and other reviews, it is a simple “match three items” kind of game. Once you match certain items on the board, you can either cancel out the items and make room for new items to drop, or you can create a special item that has special powers that may in a later turn cancel out multiple items on the board. (Very much like Candy Crush) However, what you may not have thought of is that you can only use the keyboard, so what used to be a simple task with the mouse, turned into a confusing mess.

Since this is a free-to-play game, I opted to give it a fair shot. I do think it is a cute game for young gamers, but it can be frustrating and even confusing at times. One other quick thing to keep in mind prior to installing this game is although it is free-to-play, once you run out of lives, you will have to purchase more lives to continue.
The pricing is as follows:
5 lives for 99 cents, 32 lives for $4.99, and 70 lives for $9.99

Let's be honest here.

This game is the next generation of PC gaming. Vibrant graphics, amazing UI controls, stunning mechanics, this game is the whole package. This game provides the practice of self control by showing you the characters you COULD buy, but would rather not to. Children these days need to practice self discipline to increase independence, responsibility, and self worth. reviewText:
The first thing you'll notice about when booting up this game is that it lacks mouse support.
Oddy enough however, the game does have controler support. Strange right? If you don't have a gamepad laying around you'll have to get used to using the arrow and space keys for movement.

The game itself is actually alright playing a lot like bejeweled. You match colored tiles and rack up points. Some levels are just straight up beat a score. And other levels have objectives like clear a number of colored tiles or special tiles and sometimes a mix of both score and objective.
So there is variety and fun to be had here.

But since this game is an obvious moble port you get to have all the fun that comes with that.
The fun being micro transactions. To play a stage you need to have lives. Lose a stage lose a life. That is fine. However there is no real way to earn extra guys that I have seen so far other than getting a few for a daily bonus log in. Of course there is a store to purchase extra lives. We'll get to that in a second.
There are also power ups to use while playing. Which does add some fun. The game gives you a few free ones to try out as you play. Of course when you get the power ups the game urges you to use them right away. Out of power ups now?
No problem, just like extra lives you can by power ups in the store.

Lets talk about this store now. The store has all type of things for sale. Lives, power ups, and even characters.
The prices are gross. By that I mean one life cost one dollar. Power ups? One dollar per power up. Characters cost three dollars to unlock. Now by playing I have unlocked Hans... but really who wants to play as that guy? Don't know if you can unlock all characters by playing or not. If you can I'll be sure to update saying so.

The game plays alright and I have not run into any bugs yet. I can't give this game a recommendation because of the obvious cash grab. Sure the game is simple enough and I have gone through fifteen levels so far without losing. But to be honest this game is marketed for children. And I can see them spamming power ups and running out of lives rather quickly and then asking their parents to pay for more of everything including asking for their favorite characters.
If you really want a fun match three type of game and don't already own Bejeweled 3 (one of the best match three type games in my opinion) I would have to recommend giving a look or purchasing Tomb of Tyrants, Hunie Pop (not for children), and 4 Elements. If you don't have the cash to buy a new game at the moment there is a free to play game called Battle for Blood - Epic Battles within thirty seconds. Now there is a bit of a grind in that game since it is free to play. But, there is no time restriction or need to purchase anything to beat the game.

Thanks for taking the time to read this review. Have a pleasant day.

reviewText:
The first thing you'll notice about when booting up this game is that it lacks mouse support.
Oddy enough however, the game does have controler support. Strange right? If you don't have a gamepad laying around you'll have to get used to using the arrow and space keys for movement.

The game itself is actually alright playing a lot like bejeweled. You match colored tiles and rack up points. Some levels are just straight up beat a score. And other levels have objectives like clear a number of colored tiles or special tiles and sometimes a mix of both score and objective.
So there is variety and fun to be had here.

But since this game is an obvious moble port you get to have all the fun that comes with that.
The fun being micro transactions. To play a stage you need to have lives. Lose a stage lose a life. That is fine. However there is no real way to earn extra guys that I have seen so far other than getting a few for a daily bonus log in. Of course there is a store to purchase extra lives. We'll get to that in a second.
There are also power ups to use while playing. Which does add some fun. The game gives you a few free ones to try out as you play. Of course when you get the power ups the game urges you to use them right away. Out of power ups now?
No problem, just like extra lives you can by power ups in the store.

Lets talk about this store now. The store has all type of things for sale. Lives, power ups, and even characters.
The prices are gross. By that I mean one life cost one dollar. Power ups? One dollar per power up. Characters cost three dollars to unlock. Now by playing I have unlocked Hans... but really who wants to play as that guy? Don't know if you can unlock all characters by playing or not. If you can I'll be sure to update saying so.

The game plays alright and I have not run into any bugs yet. I can't give this game a recommendation because of the obvious cash grab. Sure the game is simple enough and I have gone through fifteen levels so far without losing. But to be honest this game is marketed for children. And I can see them spamming power ups and running out of lives rather quickly and then asking their parents to pay for more of everything including asking for their favorite characters.
If you really want a fun match three type of game and don't already own Bejeweled 3 (one of the best match three type games in my opinion) I would have to recommend giving a look or purchasing Tomb of Tyrants, Hunie Pop (not for children), and 4 Elements. If you don't have the cash to buy a new game at the moment there is a free to play game called Battle for Blood - Epic Battles within thirty seconds. Now there is a bit of a grind in that game since it is free to play. But, there is no time restriction or need to purchase anything to beat the game.

Thanks for taking the time to read this review. Have a pleasant day.

reviewText:
For all you guys out there on the fence about trying a free game (regardless of whether or not its a bejeweled clone), I would like to input my thoughts.

First of all this is a phone app port! It's a casual game. A bejeweled clone. A bejeweled clone with Disney elements. As per usual for phone app's it has microtransactions (normally when it comes to lives and powerups) allowing the game to be presented for free. If you don't like bejeweled or Disney then this is not the game for you. If you like either one of those give it a shot, it's free. Also contrary to what previous reviewers think Microtransactions are completely optional.

Next people are complaining about mouse control (understandable since it is PC) but fail to comment on how easy it currently is without a mouse to play this game. Spacebar is Enter, Arrow Keys to move around, ESC to go back. Plus they remind you of the controls on nearly every page. IMO you don't need a mouse whatsoever. But they will be adding that (and Enter key functionality) sometime soon.

For a phone to PC port the game functions fairly well. The screens load nice and quickly. The graphics have also been adapted nicely that they look like they belong on the PC. Though they are also not the best of the best.

reviewText:
Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight is a military shooter in the same vein as the Battlefield or Medal of Honor franchises. The majority of the game takes place in war-stricken Afghanistan, a desolate and barren wasteland torn between military mercenaries and armed insurgents. You play as Captain Elsa McTavish, an American Forces Captain turned renegade after the loss of your dog 'Boner' in a midnight raid gone wrong.
The game claims to be open world but really this is a facade, in fact you spend all of your time in closed mission areas or a main base from which you can move out. The missions themselves usually consist of taking out military targets by force or by capture, and a few have driving sections at the beginning or end which can provide a frantic and thrilling chase. The vehicle mechanics are good but unfortunately the thing that lets this game down is the FPS element itself.
I have to say in my experience that combat just did not feel satisfying. There is a gratuitous amount of gore in this game which although realistic could be a bit over the top. The 18 rating is justified as often things come down to hand-to-hand combat, with Elsa using knives, hammers or even mislaid pens as deadly weapons.
Another important part of the game is the 'interrogation' mechanic. Sometimes to progress in a mission Elsa will take a hostage and question them for information, letting you use the environment as a weapon with which to torture your captive. The way the dialogue unwinds here is quite subtle and believable, the intense story being very well written, and smashing out somebody's teeth on a urinal to find out what they know somehow manages to retain the atmosphere of drama without seeming too funny or out of place.

Overall the game is a massive improvement on Frozen : Reckoning, but in the end it can never bring the series back to the glory of Frozen II. I'd recommend this if you want a game that's casual in terms of difficulty but still carries a heavy plot. Otherwise you'd be better sticking with the previous iterations.

reviewText:
This is a PC port of a mobile match-3 game based off Frozen animated movie.
Visuals are okay (though you don't see much of a Frozen except for some 3d models that wave at you from time to time).
Gameplay is not very original, pretty much all you come to expect from this type of games.
F2P part is pretty bad. Your lives are limited to 5 and restore very slowly, all special abilities are gained either through getting them in your daily drop or, again, buying it from the shop.
Also, as far as I can say, shop works outside of steam, so that means you will be handing money to somebody else, with all security risks that come from it.

Overall: just a mobile game that didn't really needed to come to Steam. There are much better titles out there that won't outrage you with greedy micro-transactions.

P.S.: It seems like difficulty wasn't adjusted for timed levels, which makes it nigh-impossible to get 3 stars on them using keyboard.

reviewText:
Played this gem of a match-3 on iphone for a few weeks and enjoyed it without paying a penny, though it tended to get a little tedious as levels progressed.  But it's a good family game and since my gaming rig has a touch screen I thought I'd give it a try on PC.  With an XBox-style controller in hand I fire up the game, controller recognized I proceed with gameplay - no surprises, nice.

Now time to try playing without controllers.  What? Neither mouse nor touch support under windows? (Stupifying considering how many of us gamers prefer KB & mouse over a controller!)  Controller support is just fine, but if you don't have one then you'll have to use the cursor keys to navigate the menus, as well as the actual game board.  This reminds me of early arcade games like Tetris.  Spacebar is the select/enter key.  So with no controller it's KB-only gameplay, not horrible but not 2015 either.  Hopefully touch screen and mouse support are in development as the game deserves it.

Apart for that, given the nickel & dimey nature of the game I wonder if there's going to be much of a market for this type of game on steam.  The play and graphics are pretty good, at least I thought so under iOS.  But the idea of liking it enough to splurge on perks to improve gameplay, well, it's like perpetual DLC.  This penny-bleeding model seems to work in the personal device marketplace so why not here??

Bottom line:  Unfortunately I regret installing Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight on PC, even with its small footprint.  It may be okay for tablets and smartphones, but not so much for a PC rig in its present form unless one has a controller (or two for multiplayer).  With mouse and/or touch support I might reinstall it and try it again.  But for now I'm putting this kiddie game to bed.

reviewText:
Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight is a first-person shooter game developed and published by Disney (Corporation) and is a sequel to the extremely popular and revolutionary 2009 game Bad Rats. Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight  was originally released back in 2013 and was then boasting the newly developed, highly flexible and powerful Unity Engine, it then became an instant classic by making good use of new technology, excellent storytelling, gameplay mechanics and an unrivaled online experience. Alongside its predecessor, both games left a lasting impression, particularly on the FPS genre, as an industry standard for future FPS games to come.

Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight puts the player once more behind the thick-framed bulletproof glasses of Elsa , an MIT Graduate of Thermal Physics with an uncanny ability to wield Ice and the person indirectly responsible for freezing the world and exposing Earth to an ice age that is to be known as  'Elsa's Rampage'. Frozen Free Fall: Snowball Fight is set 20 years after the events of Bad Rats and the world is now under the full control of the 'Ice', an interdimensional empire that is currently freezing the natural resources of Earth including the human race which is now close to extinction.

Enter Arendale and step once more into a freezing dress and discover a dystopian future where the only hope of humanity is a small pocket of resistance that refuses to bow down to the Ice rule. Meet old friends as well as establish new ones, explore a vast post-apocalyptic world, fight through impossible odds and stand as the last orange beacon of hope for humanities stand against extinction.
